title: 111_hr4897
content: The Act may be cited as the "Drivers Accelerated Interest Deductibility Act of 2010" or the "Drivers AID Act". Congress finds that the economic health of the United States relies on a strong automotive industry, historically accounting for 20% of retail spending. Automotive sales peaked in 2006 at 17.5 million units but have since declined, averaging less than 10 million units annually. In 2008, the automotive new vehicle dealers industry contributed significantly to the national economy with an average sales revenue of $28.8 million per dealership and a total sales of $576 billion in the United States. There were 1,057,500 employees in new-vehicle dealerships earning an average of $48,963 per year, generating a national payroll of over $52 billion. Maintaining a financially stable dealer network is crucial for the success of automobile manufacturers, especially during economic challenges. The viability of the new-vehicle dealer industry is crucial for the national economy, especially during economic challenges. Consumer confidence and incentives play a key role in new vehicle sales, impacting the automotive manufacturing industry. The deduction of nonmortgage interest payments for automobile loan debt was available for 73 years until Congress ended it in 1986. The deduction for interest on indebtedness incurred to acquire a passenger car or light truck was available for 73 years until Congress ended it in 1986. The deduction for interest on indebtedness incurred to acquire a qualified vehicle is amended to include any qualified vehicle interest if the national unemployment rate is not less than 7 percent. Qualified vehicle interest is defined as interest properly chargeable on debt incurred to acquire a qualified vehicle. The deduction for interest on indebtedness incurred to acquire a qualified vehicle is limited to $5,000 and can only be taken for interest properly allocable to a 36-month period. A qualified vehicle is defined as a motor vehicle. A qualified vehicle, as defined by the tax code, is a motor vehicle with specific criteria such as being acquired for personal use, made by a manufacturer, meeting Clean Air Act standards, having a weight rating of 6,000 pounds or less, and being a passenger vehicle. A qualified vehicle, as defined by the tax code, is a motor vehicle with specific criteria such as having a weight rating of 6,000 pounds or less and being a passenger automobile or light truck. The term 'motor vehicle' refers to any vehicle primarily manufactured for public road use with at least 4 wheels. Other terms like 'automobile', 'passenger automobile', 'light truck', and 'manufacturer' are defined by regulations set by the Environmental Protection Agency for Clean Air Act administration. The Clean Air Act allows for a deduction in adjusted gross income for qualified vehicle interest, effective from January 1, 2008. The national unemployment rate is calculated as the average of monthly rates reported by the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
